field_edited_text.value:
ProrosEp BRIDGE AT SANDY PoINT 135

636 feet laterally and 140 feet vertically. The total length of this bridge:
was slightly less than 20,000 feet. It crossed the Bay at the narrowest
point between Sandy Point and Kent Island. Beginning at the west end,
the bridge was composed of the following sections: 490 feet of beam spans
on concrete pile bents; 1750 feet of 250 feet simple deck truss spans; 2125
feet of Type C cantilevers with 500 feet main spans, 437.5 feet anchor
spans and 375 feet end spans; Type A cantilever main channel span, con-
sisting of 1200 feet main span, with 1000 feet horizontal clearance, and 600
feet anchor arms; 8587.5 feet of Type C cantilevers; 2000 feet of 250 feet
simple deck truss spans, and 2581.5 feet of beam spans on conecrete pile:
bents.

The bridge supported a 24 feet roadway and two emergency footways 18
inches wide.

The United States War Department has determined that a bridge at this
site would have to be moved south, in order to provide a longer straight-
away approach to the channel span in the navigation ship channel. The
War Department has further determined that a channel span over the east
channel will be unnecessary, but that the channel span over the west chan-
nel shall provide 1,200 feet lateral clearance, instead of 1,000 feet, with the:
same vertical clearance of 175 feet. The plans for this bridge, as shown on
Plates 66 to 82 inclusive conform to these requirements of the War De-
partment.

The West approach to the bridge on shore is 920 feet long and includes
the toll plaza. The approach then extends a distance of 2,220 feet into
the shoal waters of the Bay on filled cause-way construction, with stone
revetment to protect the causeway against erosion from wave action; then
follow sections of bridge construction consisting of 367.5 feet of beam spans;
six 100 feet girder spans; two 250 feet deck truss spans; 1210 feet of 300 feet
deck truss spans; 4620 feet of Type “C”’ cantilever construction consisting
of 450 feet end spans, 480 feet anchor spans, and 600 feet cantilever spans;
2517.5 feet of main cantilever construction across the navigation channel,
the main cantilever span of which is 1350 feet long and the side spans are
583 feet 9 inches long; 7860 feet of Type “C”’ cantilever construction with
450 feet end spans, 480 feet anchor spans, and 600 feet cantilever spans; four
250 feet deck truss spans; five 100 feet girder spans; 2335.5 feet of 61.5 feet
beam spans; 1640 feet of embankment similar to that above described for
